title: Coalition exposed on climate change, minister admits
text:
Regional anger over Australia's stance on climate change erupted at the Pacific Islands Forum in August, where Pacific leaders framed it as an existential threat to their survival.

The dispute threatens to undermine Mr Morrison's Pacific Step Up program, where he is seeking deeper ties with the Pacific amid a contest for influence with China.

Mr Hawke told the AIIA conference "there won't be walls built" around island nations to keep rising sea levels at bay but the $2 billion infrastructure financing facility available to Pacific nations incorporated a "climate window" for mitigation, adaptation and resilience projects, as well as renewable energy.

I defy anyone here to think of another country that does more on climate change in the Pacific. — Alex Hawke, International Development Minister

A further $500 million is available for spending on climate projects.

"Sometimes Australia comes under criticism for not doing enough. That we're not doing enough on climate change," he said.

"Australia is doing more than any other country. I defy anyone here to think of another country that does more on climate change in the Pacific.

"We're spending more than any other government has in Australian history to make sure we achieve this."

Advertisement

Mr Hawke also brushed off criticism that the government had not injected more money into the United Nations' green climate fund, saying that money was better spent in bilateral arrangements.

"We know through our agencies we can deliver a better outcome for Pacific partners directly. We can do more with that money on the ground in a faster way," he said.

As foreshadowed, opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Penny Wong used her speech to the conference to attack Mr Morrison for his "reckless" handling of foreign policy, particularly the relationship with China, for short-term political gain.

Following her speech, Senator Wong said it would be untrue, and a disservice to the public, to suggest that Labor risked being defined as the pro-China party, and the Coalition the anti-China party.

"What the government is doing is lurching from one press conference to another around a series of unplanned domestic political tactics when it comes to the China relationship in foreign policy," she said.

Senator Wong said Mr Morrison's recent speech to the Lowy Institute where he warned against "negative globalism" highlighted his inconsistent handling of foreign affairs.

"Scott Morrison bowls up, wants – for domestic political purposes – to rail against globalism but he’s free trade," she said.

"He’s pro-free trade. Well you can’t be pro free-trade and rail against globalism."
description: International Development Minister Alex Hawke says the government needs to do a better job selling its efforts on tackling climate change in the Pacific
